data.title: standard color of function name is ignored when the arguments is on new line
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:

**I'm using prettier extension and it recommends to break on to separates lines. VSC don't color the variable name according to function color if the arguments are not on the same line.**

Paste this in editor and you will see the standard function variable color does appear on function `findAbbreviations`, but not on `replaceAbbreviationsWithExpansions` 

```js
const findAbbreviations = (string, arrayOfAbbreviations) => {
  const stringArray = stringSplit(string);
  const abbreviationMatches = [];
  arrayOfAbbreviations.forEach(item => {
    if (stringArray.indexOf(item.abbreviation) >= 0) {
      abbreviationMatches.push({
        abbreviation: item.abbreviation,
        expansion: item.expansion
      });
    }
  });
  return abbreviationMatches;
};

const replaceAbbreviationsWithExpansions = (
  string,
  abbreviations,
  findAbbreviations
) => {
  if (findAbbreviations.length > 0) {
    const abbreviationMatches = findAbbreviations(string, abbreviations);
    let newString = string;
    abbreviationMatches.forEach(item => {
      newString = newString.replace(item.abbreviation, item.expansion);
    });
    return newString;
  } else {
    return string;
  }
};
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No
Yes

data.title: Rely on UUIDs for extension identification

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Extension identification is essential to the update mechanism. It is through an identifier that we're able to match several extension versions against one another.

We are currently using the `publisher.name` tuple as an identifier. This is very beneficial in some scenarios such as VSIX side-loading, in which updates would still work seamlessly.

The Marketplace team intends to provide publisher/extension renames. This will break our assumptions that the `publisher.name` tuple is valid during its entire lifecycle. So we must only rely on the marketplace UUID returned from the Marketplace, which will stay consistent in renaming situations.

This needs to be adopted in a few places:

- We should store the marketplace UUID into the extension's manifest, as soon as we are aware of it. Installing extensions from the Marketplace should immediately store that UUID.
- Internally, extension matching should always be based on UUID. This should be the stored marketplace UUID or, in case it is nonexistent, the tuple `publisher.name`.
- Our outdated mechanism currently prevents the loading of and deletes older versions of an extension, if multiple versions are installed into the user's extensions folder.
- At startup, whenever an installed extension is found without UUID, we should attempt to match it against a marketplace extension and, if matched, store that UUID.
- At VSIX installation time, we should attempt to match the extension against a marketplace extension and, if installed and matched, store that UUID.

cc @sandy081

data.title: showQuickPick input events?
data.body:
Hi there!

I was wondering if there is a way to get input events for the `showQuickPick` dialog? For example I want to handle the return key when all items have been filtered out, so that the QuickPick kinda acts like a combination of Input and QuickPick.

data.title: Customise ctrl+click
data.body:
Is it possible to allow the command that is executed by ctrl+click to be changed? Currently it does "go to definition", but the go to definition behaviour is frustrating, so I'd like to be able to change it to "peek definition"...

There is a stack overflow page which suggests that this functionality did once exist in Code, but it was taken out. If that's true, what was the reason?

data.title: Language definitions are not correct
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6

```javascript
function download() {
	const a = document.createElement('a');
	a.href = ''; // href: support.variable
	a.target = ''; // target: support.variable
	a.download = ''; // download: variable.other (THIS IS BAD!)
}
```

```javascript
window.navigator.userAgent.toLowerCase(); // navigator: variable.other (THIS IS BAD!)
window.location.href = '' // Here everything is good, all are support.variable
```

Even GitHub doesn't have proper language definitions and it doesn't colorize these properties ðŸ˜„ 

To see it I used `Developer: Inspect TM Scopes`.

This is a little bit annoying, because it's hard sometimes to read code when code coloring is different, because of bad language definitions theme authors can't fix it.

data.title: CTRL+P incorrectly maps to Open File on Windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: 1703

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press CTRL+P
2. Note print dialog does not appear

Expected:

* Print dialog appears (if extension present) or nothing at all if capability isn't present

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

---

Use of `CTRL+P` for printing actions roots to the beginning of Microsoft Windows and Microsoft Office UX time. Re-purposing this shortcut runs against decades of user muscle memory for no obvious gain in usability. Users will either never remember the hotkey or be slowly retrained, impacting their use of all other apps -- legacy desktop and modern --  on Windows that implement this hotkey properly today.

Do the right thing here.

data.title: workspace.openTextDocument works incorectly when passing { content?: string; } as argument
Fix #33939
data.body:
- Add protected and private visibility keywords to increaseIndentPattern
- Remove `when` keyword from decreaseIndentPattern

Before:

![private](https://i.imgur.com/wY66iNe.gif)

![when](https://i.imgur.com/bVYcuZo.gif)

Using this PR:

![private-when](https://i.imgur.com/29TGgQC.gif "bug solved")

/cc @rebornix @alexandrudima

data.title: Auto show TS suggestions for type annotation
data.body:
**Feature request**
In TypeScript for the following lines:

```ts
const z: |
```

```ts
function z(a: |
```

```ts
function z(): |
```

Where the cursor has just ended at the `|`.

At this point we should automatically show suggestions. You currently have to trigger them manually

This one needs some thought to make sure we don't trigger in incorrect locations, for example with ternary operators or object literals

data.title: Auto show JS/TS suggestions after extends / implements
data.body:
**Feature request**
In a JavaScript or TypeScript file, type out:

```js
class Foo {}

class Bar extends |
```

Where you have just finished typing `extends` followed by a space. At this point we should automatically show suggestions. You currently have to trigger them manually

The same applies for `implements`

data.title: Auto show JS/TS suggestions after new
data.body:
**Feature request**
In a js/ts file, type out:

```js
class Foo {}

new |
```

Where you have just finished typing `new` followed by a space. At this point we should automatically show suggestions. You currently have to trigger them manually

data.title: Destructuring object parameter and setting a properties default value to an array literal confuses the syntax highlighter when there's a line break
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra version 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new file
2. Set the language to JavaScript
3. Enter the following code:
```js
const a = ({
    b = []
}) => b;
```
4. Notice syntax highlighting breaks after the array literal

The problem doesn't occur if you omit the line breaks.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Firing TreeDataProvider.onDidChangeTreeData(item) doesn't fully update the item

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a, 2017-09-20T05:24:33.599Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16294
---

It seems that firing the `TreeDataProvider.onDidChangeTreeData(item)` event only causes the item's children to get refreshed (`item.getChildren` is called) and not the item itself (`item.getTreeItem` is not called).

This causes an issue if an extension is trying to update the label or icon of the item itself. For example, in GitLens I try to update an item with that has a count in its label, but the only way to get that updated is to trigger an update of the item's parent (which causes a LOT more items to get updated and recalc'd).

//cc @sandy081 

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: Opening a folder from the CLI should add it to my current workspace
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a, 2017-09-20T05:10:59.524Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have an existing window open with a few folders added in your workspace
2. `cd` to some other directory
3. run `code-insiders .` 

By default, a new window will be opened. Using `code-insiders . -r` will cause the existing window to be reloaded completely - replacing the existing workspace. Personally, I would much prefer the folder to be added to my current workspace, so that it doesn't disrupt my workflow. Do you have plans to at least add this as a configuration option?
